title: Colton Pritchett
text:
956-9764 | pri22019@byui.edu


Education

Bachelors of Computer Science | Brigham Young University - Idaho (2023 - Present)


Programming Experience
Languages: C++ | C# | Java | Python | HTML | JavaScript | CSS | Zilch Coding Environments: VSCode | Rider | IntelliJ | PyCharm | Notepad++ | Zero Engine | Android Studio | Apps Script | PowerApps | Unity

Calendar and events tracker Android App (2016)
Scripting in video games (2018-2019)
Google Sheets note sorter and reverse tag lookup (2021)
Procedural terrain generation (2024-TBD)
Various viable projects for the SIT Team (2023-present)

Experience
Landscaping | Prairie Falls Golf Course | Post Falls, ID (2018) - Cared for the grounds of the golf course - My first job at 16, taught me discipline and character
Manufacturing | Gunfighters Inc | Rathdrum, ID (2019-2020, 2023) - Started in the shipping department, later moved to manufacturing - Learned to use many tools and that I don’t want to work with my hands as a career
Missionary | The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints | Baltimore, MD (2020 - 2022) - Taught many people according to their understanding - Created, followed, and was accountable to goals and plans - Learned and became fluent in Spanish
Tech Support/Programming | SIT Team at BYUI | Rexburg, ID (2023-present) - Work with PowerApps, Apps Script, and Canvas to allow for an easy experience for both students and teachers - Created several products that each saved the team dozens of hours such as automated scripts, functional applications, etc - Worked in a team environment requiring mutual cooperation, trust, and support

title: Client Report - What’s in a Name
text:

title: Client Report - What’s in a Name
text:
paste your elevator pitch here A SHORT (4-5 SENTENCES) PARAGRAPH THAT DESCRIBES KEY INSIGHTS TAKEN FROM METRICS IN THE PROJECT RESULTS THINK TOP OR MOST IMPORTANT RESULTS.


Read and format project data
# Include and execute your code here
df = pd.read_csv("https://github.com/byuidatascience/data4names/raw/master/data-raw/names_year/names_year.csv")


Highlight the Questions and Tasks

title: Client Report - What’s in a Name
text:
QUESTION|TASK 1
How does your name at your birth year compare to its use historically?
type your results and analysis here


Read and format data
# Include and execute your code here
colton = df[df['name'] == 'Colton']
chart = px.line(colton, x='year', y='Total', title='Colton over the years')
chart.add_vline(x=2002, annotation_text="My birth")
chart.show()



                                                


include figures in chunks and discuss your findings in the figure.

title: Client Report - What’s in a Name
text:
QUESTION|TASK 2
If you talked to someone named Brittany on the phone, what is your guess of his or her age? What ages would you not guess?
1990


Read and format data
# Include and execute your code here
brittany = df[df['name'] == 'Brittany']
chart = px.line(brittany, x='year', y='Total', title='Brittany over the years')
chart.add_vline(x=1990, annotation_text="My guess")
chart.show()



                                                


include figures in chunks and discuss your findings in the figure.

title: Client Report - What’s in a Name
text:
QUESTION|TASK 3
Mary, Martha, Peter, and Paul are all Christian names. From 1920 - 2000, compare the name usage of each of the four names. What trends do you notice?
type your results and analysis here


Read and format data
# Include and execute your code here
bible_names = copy.deepcopy(df)

bible_names = bible_names[(bible_names['year'] >= 1920) & (bible_names['year'] <= 2000)]

chart = go.Figure()

names_to_plot = ['Mary', 'Martha', 'Peter', 'Paul']

for name in names_to_plot:
    name_data = bible_names[bible_names['name'] == name]
    chart.add_trace(go.Scatter(x=name_data['year'], y=name_data['Total'], mode='lines', name=name))

chart.update_layout(title='Biblical Names from 1920-2000')

chart.show()



                                                


include figures in chunks and discuss your findings in the figure.
Think of a unique name from a famous movie. Plot the usage of that name and see how changes line up with the movie release. Does it look like the movie had an effect on usage?


table example
# Include and execute your code here
sabrina = df[df['name'] == 'Sabrina']
chart = px.line(sabrina, x='year', y='Total', title='Sabrina over the years')
chart.add_vline(x=1954, annotation_text="Release of 'Sabrina'")
chart.add_vline(x=1995, annotation_text="Release of 'Sabrina' remake")
chart.show()
